item.title: Building a new website (again)
item.description:
Hello world!

It’s Tim, again.

Over the years, I’ve built many personal websites. I’ve tried so many different tools - from pure HTML/CSS static sites deployed on Github Pages, to heavy duty CMS’s like Wordpress, to Jekyll, back to Wordpress, and now – I’m using Hugo.

I’ve decided that for my needs (writing quick blog posts, on the fly), I want to prioritize my website’s speed and simplicity. I also want to save some money. So no more hosting service for now. We’re going back to good old static sites, backed up with a nice framework that will help me keep my content organized. And most importantly, fast.

item.title: How I planned a one-month solo trip to Europe
item.description:
Hello friends!

As some of you might know, I‚Äôll be taking off for ~5 weeks at the end of the year to go on a solo trip to Europe. I‚Äôm basically using up 80% of my banked up PTO in one go, so I sure hope it‚Äôll be a good time üôÇ

I figured for my newsletter this week I‚Äôd share my thought process and experience planning the trip in case you‚Äôd like to try something similar!

item.title: Lessons from writing 10 newsletter posts
item.description:
In a shocking turn of events, as of this post I‚Äôve successfully published 10 articles for my newsletter!

I‚Äôve struggled a lot with consistency in the past, and I often give up on new projects pretty quickly if I don‚Äôt get some kind of instant gratification. I‚Äôm proud (and sad) to say that this newsletter is my first creative project that I‚Äôve been able to maintain for a substantial stretch of time since I started working ‚Äúin the real world.‚Äù

item.title: The 3 levels of financial security aka F-You Money
item.description:
How much money do you need to say ‚ÄúF*** this, I‚Äôm out‚Äù?

If you grew up in an Asian immigrant household like myself, you probably grew up with a strong scarcity mindset. In other words, you never felt like you have ‚Äúenough" or you‚Äôre doing ‚Äúenough‚Äù.

You‚Äôre constantly worried that you‚Äôre falling behind relative to your peers and your goals, and you‚Äôre afraid of failure / criticism. (If this isn‚Äôt you, please tell me how your parents raised you üòÇ )

item.title: Backpacking in Ansel Adams Wilderness
item.description:
Hello friends! I‚Äôm trying something new this week by forcefully timeboxing my writing to the ~1 hour it takes for my Caltrain from Sunnyvale to the Milbrae Bart station üôÇ

This past week, the big thing I did was go on (another) backpacking trip, this time to Ansel Adams Wilderness in the Inyo National Forest! It was a 4-day 3-night trip, with Day 1 spent camping at Twin Lakes near Mammoth Lakes to rest up and acclimate to the elevation before we started hiking the next day. Day 2-4 we followed the PCT to hike from Agnew Meadows to Thousand Island Lake, looping back along the JMT/PCT to see several more incredible alpine lakes including Ruby Lake, Garnet Lake, and Shadow Lake.

item.title: Writer‚Äôs block and reflecting on big life decisions
item.description:
It‚Äôs been 3 weeks since I last published a post, which means I‚Äôm now completely off of my aspirational weekly newsletter schedule. That said, I‚Äôm not going to stress about it. Life happens!

Over the last few weeks, I celebrated my (actual) 25th birthday, visited Christine in Vancouver, and went on a backpacking trip to Yosemite. In between all the traveling, spending time with loved ones, and keeping up with work, I haven‚Äôt had much time or energy to sit down for a couple hours to write up a post.

item.title: 5 things I love to spend money on
item.description:
One of the most popular posts of all time on r/financialindependence is to Build the life you want, then save for it.

The general message is that instead of cutting back on everything (lattes, trips, etc.) to save for an ambiguous idea of what your life might look like in 20 years, you should invest in building a life that makes you feel more fulfilled today. That way, you have something you actually want to save for.

item.title: Why Coast FIRE is my favorite financial milestone
item.description:
Coast FIRE is one of my favorite ideas in personal finance, and it‚Äôs a milestone that I think will resonate with my fellow Gen Z.

For those not familiar with the term, FIRE = Financial Independence, Retire Early. The FIRE movement initially gained traction in the early 2010s, particularly among people working high income jobs in tech who lived frugal lifestyles. This combination allowed FIRE practitioners to aggressively invest for retirement, with the target of saving over 25x of their annual expenses to be considered ‚Äúfinancially independent‚Äù. If they hit this milestone early enough, they could ‚Äúretire early‚Äù, often in their 30s or 40s.

item.title: Travel Journal #2 - Discovering North Carolina and attending a meat conference
item.description:
Last week, I got the chance to travel all throughout North Carolina.

I spent 3 days in Raleigh, 3 days in Boone (for the MEAT üçñ conference), 0.5 day in Greensboro, and 3 days in Charlotte.

Charlotte ‚Üí Raleigh ‚Üí Boone ‚Üí Greensboro ‚Üí Charlotte

‚õ∞Ô∏è Discovering North Carolina

1. North Carolina is green!!!

Apparently North Carolina‚Äôs climate is considered sub-tropical, and even in the cities it was dense with trees and insects (so many beetles). To me, the weather felt similar to Hawaii - it was warm and humid, with occasional random showers in the middle of the day.

item.title: Travel Journal #1 - The one where I stayed in airports all day
item.description:
I had quite a wild travel itinerary this week.

I went from Vancouver to San Francisco, San Francisco to Calgary, Calgary to Vancouver, Vancouver to Charlotte, and then Charlotte to Raleigh, hitting a total of 5 different airports in less than 24 hours.

  • 7/23: YVR ‚Üí SFO
  • 7/25: SFO ‚Üí YYC
  • 7/25: YYC ‚Üí YVR
  • 7/26 - 7/27: YVR ‚Üí CLT
  • 7/27: CLT ‚Üí RDU

I originally flew in to Vancouver on 7/20, but due to a family emergency, my trip to Vancouver was cut short and I ended up flying back to Pleasanton for a few days (7/23-7/25).

item.title: How I overcame my limiting beliefs
item.description:
Hello friends, welcome to my first newsletter post!

After procrastinating for years, I‚Äôve decided it‚Äôs finally time for me to start a newsletter. Credit to my friend Manan who started his own newsletter recently for inspiring me to get started.

Why am I doing this?

I have a couple of goals for this newsletter (in no particular order):

  1. Start creating instead of consuming and help people at scale. For a long time, I‚Äôve been in ‚Äúlearn‚Äù mode about topics that interest me. Even though there‚Äôs still a ton for me to learn, I‚Äôve hit a point where people have started to ask me questions and ask for help (which I‚Äôm more than happy to provide). I‚Äôd love to make the information I share during 1:1 conversations more widely available to others, and I figure the easiest way to do so is by writing and posting it to the internet üôÇ

item.title: Projects
item.description:
Personal website - aggregating all my stuff

Newsletter - regular reflections and life updates in your inbox

Soryun (Nov 2025) - read in your target language and acquire new words organically

Learning Japanese - somewhere between N4-N3

Cafe reviews - Keeping track of all the cafes I’ve enjoyed
